summary: This document outlines revised Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policies and procedures at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY) regarding suicide prevention, inmate housing (particularly single-cell placement and cellmate assignments), documentation accuracy, and the management of high-profile inmates and sex offenders. It appears to be a response or reconstruction following an incident, detailing systemic changes to prevent future issues.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: The senior official at MCC-NY who is notified of inmates placed on or off suicide watch and determines their housing placement and observation details.

persons.name: Chief Psychologist
persons.context: Leads the Psychology Department, counsels staff on documentation, monitors log books, provides training, and offers feedback on managing sex offender inmates at executive meetings.

persons.name: Drug Abuse Coordinator
persons.context: A shared supervisory position that counseled a Drug Treatment Specialist (DTS) about documentation errors. The Warden is working to re-establish this as a full-time position.

persons.name: Drug Treatment Specialist
persons.context: A staff member who was counseled for incorrectly documenting in a suicide watch log book, though with no ill intent, as she was trying to assist an officer.

persons.name: Staff Attorney
persons.context: Assists when an inmate's attorney or the court expresses concerns about the inmate, particularly regarding mental health or housing needs.

persons.name: Associate Warden, Programs
persons.context: An executive staff member who is notified if there are inconsistencies in the daily SENTRY roster of inmates on suicide watch in the hospital area.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Discusses inmate needs in meetings and is to be notified immediately if hourly rounds or log book signings by Lieutenants and Unit Officers are not being conducted, to enforce accountability.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: Notified when inmates are removed from suicide watch for cellmate placement. Required to sign suicide watch log books each shift and receive additional training. The SHU Lieutenant examines training sign-in sheets.

persons.name: Staff Psychologist
persons.context: Psychology staff members who interview inmates, review documentation, and are to be contacted verbally for mental health concerns. A second Staff Psychologist has been added to help reduce workload.

persons.name: Unit 2 Officer
persons.context: Assigned to round the suicide watch area hourly and sign the suicide watch log books during their Unit 2 rounds.

persons.name: Unit Officer
persons.context: A general reference to officers who round the suicide area hourly and sign log books. Their failure to conduct rounds triggers notification to the Captain.

connections.description: The Chief Psychologist, along with the Drug Abuse Coordinator, counseled the DTS concerning errors in her documentation in the suicide watch log book.
Both are part of the executive staff and collaborate on decisions regarding inmate housing, suicide watch status, and staffing (e.g., re-establishing the Drug Abuse Coordinator position).
Psychology staff verbally notify Lieutenants when inmates are removed from suicide watch for cellmate placement, and both groups receive joint training on procedures.
The Captain is to be notified if Lieutenants fail to perform required rounds and sign log books, and will then enforce accountability.
The Staff Attorney assists when concerns are raised by an inmate's attorney or the court regarding the inmate's treatment or housing.

locations.name: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY)
locations.context: The federal detention facility where these revised suicide prevention and inmate management policies are being implemented.

locations.name: Hospital Area (H01)
locations.context: The specific area within MCC-NY containing suicide watch cells (H01-001L to H01-004L).

locations.name: Special Housing Unit (SHU)
locations.context: A segregated unit within the prison discussed in meetings and for which specific suicide prevention training is conducted.

keyFacts: The Psychology Department has eliminated 'Psychological Observation' status at MCC-NY to avoid confusion about inmate needs, indicating a policy overhaul.
A system is now in place to prevent single-celling, with specific procedures involving the Warden, Psychology, and Lieutenants to ensure at-risk inmates have cellmates after suicide watch.
Suicide watch log books are now strictly controlled; only the staff member directly observing the inmate may document in them, and they are monitored daily by the Chief Psychologist.

The document mentions using 'PSY ALERT codes more frequently with high profile cases and with inmates with a history or charge of a sex offense,' suggesting special protocols for certain inmate categories.
Legal visits for inmates on suicide watch require prior authorization from Psychology, Lieutenants, and the Captain, and involve continuous staff observation with 15-minute documentation intervals.
